report_title: Pet Funeral and Cremation Services Industry Report
executive_summary: The increasing cost of conventional burial services, especially in population centers with diminished cemetery space, has prompted consumers to consider lower-cost cremation. However, traditional burials still remain the most popular service offered. Additionally, households increasingly view their pets as an integral part of the family. This, combined with a rising pet ownership rate, has boosted demand for pet burial and cremation services. Overall, industry revenue increased at a CAGR of 12.5% to $1.3 billion over the past five years, including a 1.3% increase in 2024 alone. The jump in 2024 can be mainly attributed to the continued growth in the number of household pets throughout the past five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The image shows a graph depicting the number of cats and dogs in the US surging in 2020 as COVID-19 lockdowns led consumers to look for companionship by adopting a pet.

Revenue growth has helped funeral homes and cremators better handle fixed costs, like rent and utilities. Prices have also increased ahead of input costs, and automation is reducing the impact of rising wage expenses. The higher concentration of private pet cremations is also a boon to large companies seeking to lift prices as competition is reduced.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While consumers will continue to demand premium services for their pets, the price of key expenses will drop during the first half of the outlook period. Funeral homes and cremators use a large amount of natural gas and electricity to operate efficiently, and declining prices will enable some struggling companies to lower prices and undercut competitors. Declining prices will temper revenue growth and make the industry more competitive.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: With Improving Economic Conditions, Demand for Pets Will Continue Rising
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rise in the number of pets will continue to boost demand for pet funeral and cremation services as per capita disposable income grows and economic conditions improve.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry are primarily engaged in preparing deceased pets for burial or interment and conducting funerals (i.e. providing facilities for wakes, arranging transportation for the deceased and selling caskets and related merchandise).

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: The price of funerals and cremations is a major form of competition.
Cremation and funeral providers must ensure that prices are competitive so that customers remain loyal.

Pet funeral and cremation facilities benefit from being located near veterinarians and other animal clinics. By operating near these facilities, operators can minimize costs spent on acquiring key customers.
Revenue still climbed at the height of the pandemic
Growth will slow over the next five years
Pet funeral homes and cremators don't benefit from any specific government assistance
The increasing diversity of the population has improved demand for the industry's services
Purchases consist of the newest cremation equipment and memorial products
Labor is relied on for each service offering
Pet funeral and cremation services focus primarily on cats and dogs.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Pet owners that are represented in this segment are typically the least likely to purchase high-profit services due to budgetary constraints. Although these pets owners still consider their pets to be like family members, this segment is less likely to be able to afford private cremation services or other upsells.

Pet owners that are represented in this segment are more likely to purchase high-profit services than those in the lower earning segment. Pet owners in this segment also consider their pets like family members. However, this segment has more discretionary income to purchase higher profit services.

This segment refers to households that own pets and earn more than $150,000. This segment accounts for the largest share of revenue. As with the other markets, this segment also considers their pets as family members. However, this market is able and willing to purchase the highest profit services.

products_and_services.product_description: Dog cremation services involve the cremation of dogs. This can be done privately or in a communal cremator. Communal cremations are always the most affordable, as there are multiple pets in one cremator. People who choose private cremations end up purchasing more products, such as memorial urns.

Cat cremation services involve the cremation of cats. As with dog cremation services, this can also be done privately or in a communal cremator. The only difference between dog and cat cremations is typically the pet's size and the cremation cost.

Pet funeral services involve the service and burial of a pet. Pet funeral services are typically the most profitable product offering, as there are many add-ons consumers can purchase for a funeral service.

Other pet cremation services involve the cremation of pets other than dogs or cats. Although this product service offers cremation services for other pets, the types of additional services and products offered are still the same as the dog or cat cremation services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: In recent years, a growing number of pet owners have opted to cremate or bury their deceased pets. Consequently, the total number of pets in the United States affects the number of pets that can potentially be cremated or buried, thus affecting demand for industry services.

The number of cremations compared with traditional burials is the strongest driver of industry growth. Demand for cremation has increased over the past five years due to cost considerations, environmental reasons, religious considerations and changing consumer preferences.

The cost of cremation is considerably lower than a traditional funeral. Consequently, changes in per capita disposable income influence pet owners' preferences for cremation or burial services. As disposable income levels rise, they can spur purchases of additional industry merchandise and services, which favorably affects revenue.

According to the American Pet Products Association's survey, 67.0% of US households own a pet. Consequently, an increase in the number of households will likely increase the number of pets in the United States, supporting industry demand.

basis_points.basis_title: Price of funerals and cremations is a major form of competition
basis_points.basis_description: Cremation and funeral providers must ensure that prices are competitive so

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Costs Have Declined as Equipment Technology Improves
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages represent the highest cost of funeral and cremation services. This refers only to the labor costs associated with offering the funeral or cremation services; most industry establishments are funeral homes that provide a range of other services, and therefore have additional wage costs pertaining to other operations. Although funeral and cremation employees have been hired in line with growth in demand, industry revenue growth has surpassed growth in wage expenses during the five-year period.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Innovation Lies in the Digitization of Services
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although the industry's services are already very well accepted, operators can innovate through technological growth. Since cremation requires some heavy machinery, operators can innovate by making the process more efficient.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Certain types of cremation services come with a higher price tag than other alternatives, so high per capita disposable income is essential for sales.

FAQs.question: What is the document about?
FAQs.answer: The document contains industry data in the form of a table with columns for year, revenue, enterprises, establishments, employment, wages, IVA, imports, and exports over the years 2005 to 2016.
